description:
Write an essay addressing the following question, related to the content from the Prologue and Chapter one of The Shallows: What the Internet Is Doing to Our Brain       

    • In what ways might our increasing reliance on technology be affecting our ability to think deeply and critically?

Minimum word count: 500;  Maximum word count: 800

Use MLA format for any citations/references.

Your writing for this assignment will be submitted to the TurnIn anti-plagiarism service, which flags plagiarism and AI generated content.  You will be shown the TurnIn report and can submit up to 3 times (total) to fix any flagged problems.  Final submissions that are flagged by the plagiarism or AI checker may be rejected.

You will need to also Peer Review three randomly assigned submissions for this assignment from other students and provide your feedback. You must fill out the Rubric points on the Peer Review to receive credit for your review. Please be constructive with criticism.  I will be able to view your feedback and know who submitted it, but your feedback will be anonymous to other students.  This feedback is counted under a separate grading category for the semester (see Syllabus).  Peer Review Feedback is due no later than one week after the original due date for each writing assignment.

Between the due date/time and the cut-off date/time, there is a 5% per-day late penalty. This assignment will become unavailable after the cut-off date/time.
name: Writing Assignment #1

rubric.long_description: Good sentence structure avoids unnecessary wordiness. It expresses ideas in a succinct manner, using only the words needed to convey the message.

A complete sentence contains both a subject (who or what the sentence is about) and a predicate (what the subject is doing or what is happening to the subject). Incomplete sentences can lead to confusion.
Proper subject-verb agreement, appropriate verb tense usage, and accurate use of pronouns contribute to correct sentence structure.
The active voice (subject performing the action) is generally preferred over the passive voice (subject receiving the action) because it is more direct and dynamic.
Sentences should be of appropriate length for the content. While some sentences can be short for emphasis, overly long sentences can be hard to follow.
Sentence structure should be crafted to avoid ambiguity. Ambiguous sentences can be interpreted in multiple ways, leading to confusion.

Each paragraph should start with a clear and concise topic sentence that introduces the main idea or point of the paragraph. This sentence sets the tone for the rest of the paragraph and guides the reader's understanding.

Unity: A well-structured paragraph focuses on a single main idea or theme. All sentences within the paragraph should support or elaborate on this central idea. Irrelevant or off-topic information should be avoided.
Arrange sentences within a paragraph in a logical order that makes sense to the reader. This could be chronological, sequential, cause-effect, or any other structure that suits the content.

When moving from one paragraph to the next, use transition sentences to link ideas and guide the reader through the flow of the text. These sentences help show the relationship between the paragraphs.
A paragraph should be long enough to adequately develop its main idea, but not so long that it becomes overwhelming or confusing.
The degree to which you completely addressed all of the assigned topics and/or questions.

Correct punctuation is essential for conveying your intended meaning accurately and preventing misunderstandings. It helps to structure sentences, indicate relationships between ideas, and guide the reader's interpretation. Adhering to proper punctuation rules enhances the professionalism and effectiveness of your writing.

Possible "other" score deductions include: Overuse of quotations (your submission should not contain more than about 10-20% quoted material). Incorrect or missing citations. Word count outside allowed range.

You might also receive additional points under "other" for overall excellence above and beyond expectations. Note: Simply providing a word count on the higher end of the range will not necessarily result in bonus points. Be concise.

description: This is just a placeholder for the in-class writing assignment grade.
name: In-Class Writing Assignment

description:
In Chapter 4 of our book, "The Shallows: The Deeping Page", the author quotes a poem by Wallace Stevens, "The House was Quiet and the World was Calm":

"The house was quiet and the world was calm.
The reader became the book; and summer night
Was like the conscious being of the book.
The house was quiet and the world was calm.
The words were spoken as if there was no book,
Except that the reader leaned above the page,
Wanted to lean, wanted much most to be
The scholar to whom his book is true, to whom
The summer night is like a perfection of thought.
The house was quiet because it had to be.
The quiet was part of the meaning, part of the mind:
The access of perfection to the page."

Reflect on this poem and how it relates the themes from Chapter 4.  Choose three themes from the chapter that relate to this poem and explain how they relate to the poem.  And finally, in your concluding paragraph, end by answering: How does this poem make you feel about "deep reading" and your relationship to non-digital print media?

Structure your essay with a one paragraph introduction, one paragraph per topic, then a concluding paragraph.

The total word count must be between 500 and 800 words.  Each paragraph must have at least four complete sentences.  Each citation must reference one item from a bibliography at the bottom, and include the page number for printed materials.
name: Writing Assignment #2

rubric.long_description: The degree to which you covered the assigned topic, and the content and organization of your writing (excluding the grammar, spelling, punctuation, etc.)

description:
Daily Meditation Challenge

Source: Google Images

You can earn up to a 10% boost on your overall attendance score by submitting a weekly Meditation Journal via this assignment.  

View this quick introductory video: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=o-kMJBWk9E0

Then begin your meditation journey!  Shoot for one 10 minute meditation per day.  First thing in the morning, or last thing at night will likely be the easiest times. 

To earn your extra credit, simply keep a journal of your daily experiences, and any changes you notice over time as you continue your practice.  The entries can be brief, just noting the date / time for each entry, and a sentence or two.  For example:

  • Sept. 16th, 8am: Tried meditating for 10 minutes.  It was very challenging to stay with it, but I pushed through and got to 10 minutes.  No effects noticed so far.

I recommend keeping your journal in a google doc.  You may submit your final journal at the end of week 15 for up to a 10% boost on your attendance score.  You must print your final journal to pdf format before submitting.

A nice aid to meditation is a simple app that times the meditation, and optionally plays some soothing background music or sounds as you meditate.  Here is a good one that is free:  https://insig.ht/fmR7NE2vWMb

As an additional motivation, here is a list of scientifically validated benefits of maintaining a daily meditation practice:

  • Reduces Stress: Helps decrease stress by promoting relaxation and reducing the levels of stress hormones like cortisol.
  • Enhances Emotional Health: Improves mood and emotional well-being, reducing symptoms of depression and anxiety.
  • Increases Self-Awareness: Enhances self-awareness and fosters a better understanding of oneself and one's thoughts.
  • Improves Focus and Concentration: Enhances attention span and concentration, leading to better productivity and task performance.
  • Promotes Emotional Regulation: Helps manage and regulate emotions, leading to greater emotional stability.
  • Improves Sleep: Enhances sleep quality by calming the mind and reducing the factors that contribute to sleep disturbances.
  • Reduces Age-Related Memory Loss: Supports cognitive functions and can improve memory in older adults.
  • Supports Mental Health: Alleviates symptoms of mental health issues like depression, anxiety, and PTSD.
  • Boosts Immune System: Enhances the immune response, promoting better overall health.
  • Increases Kindness and Compassion: Encourages empathy, compassion, and kindness toward oneself and others.
  • Reduces Pain: Helps reduce the perception of pain through mind-body awareness.
  • Enhances Creativity: Promotes creative thinking by allowing the mind to relax and think freely.
  • Improves Physical Health: Lowers blood pressure, reduces heart rate, and promotes overall cardiovascular health.

Ascend the "Emotional Spiral" of Life Through Mindfulness Meditation

Source: https://www.suzannakennedy.com/blog/ascending-spiral
